title: Are all highly intelligent people creative? - Quora

response.answer_text: There really is no objective way of justifying any answer, but here’s my attempt. No. As someone who’s been around lots of intelligent people, the only standard I see is that there is NONE. Some are really good at video games. They tend to have good reflexes, and situational awareness. Some have really good memories. Their retention rate is unreal. They tend to be good at standardized tests and academics. Some are very people smart. They know what you are going to say before you say it. They know the right things to say, and tend to be outgoing. Some are deep, abstract thinkers. These are your physicists, philosophers, and mathematicians. They excel at theory, strategy, and problem-solving. Others have good verbal skills. They learn languages well. They often are good writers, though it’s not a given. From experience, the more creative ones think outside the box. They’re not relegated to conventions. They always find different ways of making music, solving problems, or creating policies. Which finally brings me to my conclusion. Many intelligent folks are good at regurgitation. They are great information processors. They learn quickly, retain, and draw conclusions; but often, they are streamlined thinkers- borderline computers, if you will. They come up with nothing new. Their line of thinking is hackneyed, and is of on worn paths. Academically, these are the ones who get 4.0’s easily, but are terrible at research. You’d be surprised at how many they are. On the other hand, several creative people I’ve met aren’t that intelligent. They’re good at finding new ways of expression. Hopefully a neuroscientist can explain why…I’m at a loss.

Everyone is creative to some extent even if they make bird houses out of popsicle sticks. The real link between the mind & creativity comes at the knife’s edge of intellect, mental illness & artistic ability. I know because I’m balancing ther now. The link has been well known, but anecdotal for centuries. Scientists are researching it now. Creating is wonderful, but the constant balancing act is enormously draining. Research the lives of creative people. You can even shortcut the work & google a list of creative people with mental illness. Yes, intelligent people can be highly creative. They can also be boring statisticians & bank clerk who doodle a lot.

Honestly, I can’t answer your question with absolute fact. Only a guess. In school, one of the main tests for getting into the gifted program is creativity. Generally, the ones who are the most creative are let into the gifted program. This does not say that ALL gifted people are creative, but they have a higher chance of it, if not because of their ability to think more in depth, then possibly because they tend to get bored more easily, and make something up to entertain themselves. I had a whole society made up from the time I was about 5 to when a I was 12, I literally had daily checkups where I would imagine what happened in that society. This was quite the advantage to me when taking creativity tests, simply because I had been thinking like that from a young age. I hope this was helpful, if not exactly the answer you were looking for.

I think creativity is a skill one can learn, and given how useful being creative is and how intelligent people tend to teach themselves useful skills, there is generally at least seems to be something of a correlation between creativity and intelligence. However it is conceivable that somebody could be highly intelligent and simply not very creative as they are not dependent on each other directly in any way I am aware of. It also depends on how you define intelligence and creativity, as there does some to be variations in perceptions of the meanings of such words.

I've been tested to have an IQ of 163 and no I'm not creative at all. I've got poor fine motor skills. I can't draw and my hand writing is awful. You ask me to draw, I'll respond with “what would you like” you respond with “anything”. I'll draw a basic house with a sun and some grass. You'll look at it like someone in kindergarten did it. However if you ask me to come up with a solution to a problem. I'll give you 3 options and none will be aesthetically pleasing. I only look for 2 things in solving problems. 1. It's simple 2. It works.
